section1P1: If you've ever been around Argentines during a football tournament, you've probably heard the word prode. At the office, at the stadium, at the weekend barbecue: "hey, are we setting up a prode for the World Cup?" is a phrase that gets repeated every time a major tournament kicks off. But the history behind that word runs much deeper than it appears at first glance.
section1P2: It all started in 1972, when the Argentine government officially launched the PRODE (Pronosticos Deportivos — Sports Predictions). It was a state-run system where citizens went to their local kiosk, bought a printed card and marked their predictions for the matchday of Argentine football. You marked 1 (home win), X (draw) or 2 (away win) for each game. If you got them all right, you won the accumulated jackpot. That simple, that addictive.
section1P3: The PRODE quickly became a massive social phenomenon. On Friday afternoons, the queues at kiosks were part of the urban landscape of Buenos Aires, Rosario, Cordoba, Mendoza and every city across the country. On Mondays, the first conversation at any office in Argentina started with "how'd you do in the prode?". It didn't matter if you were a football fanatic or could barely tell offside from a corner kick — everyone played the prode. It was a collective ritual that crossed social classes, ages and levels of football knowledge.
section1P4: The official PRODE was discontinued in 1998 after the privatization of the National Lottery, but the word remained permanently etched in the Argentine vocabulary. Today, more than 50 years after its creation, when a group of friends organizes predictions for the World Cup, Champions League or the South American qualifiers, they still call it a "prode". In other countries they use different words: quiniela in Mexico, polla in Colombia and Chile, penca in Uruguay. But in Argentina, the prode is the prode — and the tradition is immortal.

closingP1: The prode has something that no fantasy sports app or prediction house can replicate: the personal factor.
